Abstract—Power systems are experiencing a rapid and dra-
matic transformation driven by the massive integration of non-
dispatchable renewable energy sources such as wind and solar
and highly variable loads such as electric vehicles and air
conditioning. This challenges existing grid assets eventually
leading to update them which in turn increase signiﬁcantly
the costs of the sustainable technologies. Power electronics is a
pivotal technology for electrical power processing for renewable
energies and sustainable transportation. By means of ”smart”
functionalities power electronics converters already embedded in
such applications, can also contribute to guaranteeing the overall
system stable operation. Anyway this cooperative contribution
from distributed devices may be not enough leading to the need
in the voltage transformation and power transmission of ”system
level” power electronics solutions. In the case of large charging
stations a Smart Transformer while in the case of large solar and
wind parks integration Medium or High Voltage Direct Current
Transmission are system level solutions. This paper wants to
review the potential of using such infrastructures to increase
the capacity of existing grid assets avoiding or deferring their
upgrade and hence reducing the overall costs of renewables
integration and of the electriﬁcation of transport sector. In fact
the power converters embedded in Smart Transformer (ST)
and High Voltage Direct Current (HVDC) can provide fast
frequency and voltage response and precise control of power
ﬂow acting at system level much more effectively and feasibly for
system operators as the distributed power converters embedded
in several small sources and users. This paper reviews for
the ﬁrst time these two key power electronics ”system level”
solutions together - Smart Transformer and High Voltage Direct
Current - starting from their basic functionalities and showings
how they can go beyond them showing how with grid forming
functionalities they can offer new ”Smart Grid” tools to enhance
the capability of the existing electric grid infrastructures.

I. I NTRODUCTION
Electrical grids are suffering large demand variability
caused mainly by highly variable loads such as air con-
ditioning and electric vehicles [1]. The broader integration
of renewable energies such as wind and solar is expected
to worsen the situation resulting in further congestion and
underutilization of the electrical network [2]. Most of these
loads and energy sources are connected to the grid by using
power electronics converters.
However during the last years, it has been registered not
only a steadily increasing number of distributed power elec-
tronics converters but also ”system level” power electronics
converters have been embedded into the electrical grid to
perform a multitude of tasks, as shown in Fig. 1. Due to
the fast dynamical response of currents and voltages, these
converters are used in a STATic COMpensator (STATCOM)
to control reactive power, maintaining the voltage amplitude
at a given level and increasing the transmission capability of
the lines. Also, they are employed to manage Energy Storage
Systems (ESS) to inject active power providing fast frequency
regulation. High V oltage dc (HVDC) systems offer a cost-
effective solution for long-distance bulk energy transmission.
Smart Transformers (ST) provide voltage level transformation
and a wide variety of ancillary services such as reactive power
compensation, harmonic ﬁltering, voltage sag compensation,
frequency regulation, dc grids, among others [3].
Despite distributed and system-level power converters have
become an essential component of power grids [4], they are
usually associated with the reduction of system inertia, sub-
synchronous oscillations, and other problems. Recent analyses
show that a change in the control strategies can attenuate these
issues allowing to take real advantage of the controllability and
ﬂexibility power converters bring to the electrical grid [5].
Power electronics-interfaced renewable energies, such as
wind turbines and PV plants, offer no rotational inertia to
the system. This reduced inertia increases the rate of change
of frequency (RoCoF) that may trigger frequency relays and
causes the automatic under-frequency load shedding. Alterna-
tive frequency support methods for low inertia power systems,
such as virtual inertia, have been proposed. The virtual inertia

In transmission systems the power ﬂow is mostly uncon-

and introduce more controllability in the ac system is the well-

is attempting to give the electrical grid more ﬂexibility in
controlling the power ﬂow.
Also, at the distribution level is possible to increase the

demonstrated that the improvement of voltage controllability
can unlock up to 3,2 GW of untapped potential [12]. This
increment of grid capacity can be done through Smart Trans-
formers which can control the voltage proﬁle, increasing the
damping in case of power mismatch [13]. Consequently, the
larger damping reduces the Rate of Change of Frequency
(ROCOF), allowing the increase of wind penetration up to
20 % [6]. In general, to increase the damping of the system
using distributed generation requires a grid forming control
scheme [4].
This paper reviews both smart voltage transformation and
transmission starting from classifying the adopted operation
as grid following and grid forming, since the latter has been
emerging in the last years as fundamental contribution to the
electric grid stability, then protections in power electronics
dominated grid are discussed. In the following the two main
technologies, Smart Transformer and HVDC, are reviewed,
focusing on their conﬁgurations and features but also the
challenges these devices and their associated control schemes
must withstand. Although only two applications are described,
its operation and challenges are common to other applications
such as active ﬁlters, ESSs and others. Furthermore, STs

II. I NTEGRATION OF POWER ELECTRONICS CONVERTERS
INTO THE ELECTRIC GRID
Distributed Power Generation System (DPGS) based on
renewable resources such as wind and solar, as well as
STATCOM, ESS, HVDC and ST devices are integrated into
the electrical grid through power electronics converters fol-
lowing the conﬁguration shown in Figure 2. The converter is
controlled by the modulation voltage and is connected to the
point of common coupling (PCC) using a ﬁlter.
The control strategy of converters can be conﬁgured as
either grid-following (GFL) mode or grid forming (GFM)
mode, which entitles converters the characteristics of a current
source or a voltage source, respectively. A correct operation of
GFL converters needs to identify the electric grid impedance
and design correctly the PLL, while GFM converters may rein-
force the system stability. Main differences of GFM and GFL
converters are summarized in following aspects: i) operation
principle, ii) response to grid events and iii) synchronization
processes [14].
A. Grid Following and Grid Forming Operation
Grid connected power converters are conventionally con-
trolled in GFL mode acting as a controlled current source
following the frequency of the reference voltage. Converters
with GFL were originally designed to deliver power to the grid
by controlling the current, synchronizing its operation with
the grid voltage. This control strategy can increase the grid
stability by controlling active and reactive power depending
on the demand but it does not give support to the grid voltage
if this is weak or not existent. The performance of the GFL
is usually affected by the grid voltage condition, as well as,
interactions with other power converters in the grid can cause
voltage and frequency alterations.
Power converters can be otherwise controlled in GFM
mode generating a voltage source at its terminals for other
converters and loads. The concept of GFM converter was
ﬁrstly introduced in microgrid applications to enhance system
stability and resiliency of power grid with high percentage
of power-electronics-based energy generation. Unlike GFL
operation mode, the GFM regulates the active or reactive
power by directly controlling its voltage at output terminals
generating a voltage source. This operation mode can create a
voltage in a node were there are no other generators connected

C. Synchronization Approach
The GFL controller needs a synchronization unit which is
often implemented by a Phase-Locked-Loop (PLL) [18]. Fig.
6 (a) shows a typical control scheme of synchronous reference
frame PLL. As seen in the ﬁgure, it identiﬁes the amplitude
and phase angle of the grid by sampling the three-phase grid
voltages. The amplitude and phase shift of output current
can be calculated according to the deﬁned active power and
reactive power.
Although the PLL shows good performance in identifying
grid voltages, it can generate stability issues to the converter
under weak grid condition, which could be overcame at cost
of control bandwidth of PLL. Conversely, the decrease of the
control bandwidth leads to poor dynamics of acquiring grid
voltage angle which cannot satisfy the requirement of quick
reactions to grid faults [19]. The bandwidth of PLL will be
limited when the converter operates at low short-circuit-ratio
(SCR) grid and there are other PLL-based converters nearby.

As for GFM converter, it can be self-synchronized to the
grid by power control approached which emulates the power
synchronization principles of a real synchronous generator
(SG) , such as power synchronization control [20], droop
control [21] and synchronverter control [22]. Synchroniza-

popular because it doesn’t require a different unit for pre-

synchronization control is shown in Fig. 6 b). Results indicate

behave instablity under stiff grid condition [24].
With the increasing penetration of renewable energy and
distributed energy resources (DERs), the inertia offered by SGs
to the system is decreased, which leads to frequency stability
issues [25]. Operators in South Australia are already facing
obstacles regarding the high penetration of inverter-based
sources during certain periods of the day [26]. Due to different
output characteristics of GFL converter and GFM converter,
their response to frequency variation would be different. For a
mixed system which includes SGs, GFM converters and GFL
converters, the increase share of GFM converters helps to pro-
vide more damping to frequency swing while GFL converters
generates the opposite effect with the increase of its share [4].
Therefore, reserves of GFM converters in a low-inertia system
has the potential to greatly reduce frequency swings as well
as reduce rate of change of frequency (ROCOF), allowing a
larger percentage of power converters integrated to the grid.
D. Challenges for Grid Forming Operation
Although GFM control has better frequency response than
GFL and enhances system stability, there are still many
challenges needed to be addressed.
a) Synchronization stability: It’s of great signiﬁcance for a
converter to keep synchronization with the grid. In GFM
mode the current injected to the grid can be derived by
the power angle relationship between the grid voltage and
the equivalent output voltage of the converter. Under stiff
grid condition, even a small disturbance of grid voltage can
lead to an instantaneous change of current, causing large
power variations. Therefore, control method with much
more damping and robustness against large variation of
SCR are required [27].
b) Synchronization during faults: During severe grid faults the
transient stability of GFM control with power synchroniza-
tion and synthetic inertia exhibits a second-order nonlinear
dynamics behavior, which is similar to the power-swing
dynamics of SGs [28]. The fault current is generally con-
trolled by the PLL, which also performs similar dynamics
as the power-swing dynamics of SGs potentially triggering
the over-current protection during the transient [29]. There-
fore, a PLL approach to perform faster dynamics during
severe grid faults should be investigated.
c) Current limitation and fault-ride through (FRT): Under
grid faults, over-currents may damage the hardware of the
converter or may trigger over-current protection. Therefore,
proper strategies to deal with over-currents, as well as, ride
through strategies should be implemented [30].
d) Transition between islanded and grid-connected modes:
The converter may be disconnected from the grid during
fault, which may causes signiﬁcant deviations and oscilla-
tions due to the undesired mismatch of frequency, voltage
or non-zero through-power. Therefore, strategies that can
be applied in the grid-connected mode and the islanded
mode are required ensuring seamless-transitions between
both operating modes [31].
E. Power system protection with increasing power electronic
converter integration
The conventional power system protection is based on
current sensing devices, such as over-current relays, reclosers
and fuses [32]. These devices monitor the fault current ﬂow
and generate trip signals to the circuit breaker in case the
fault current exceeds a pre-deﬁned threshold. However, this
approach is based on the assumption of radial feeders and
unidirectional power ﬂow, which isn’t necessarily true with the
increasing penetration of power electronics based RES [33].
Moreover, the RES change the fault level (as they contribute
only with small portion to the fault currents) and havevariable
power in-feed by nature. In consequence, the conventional
power system protection experiences a number of challenges
[32]: 1) Blinding of protection, i.e. upstream relays will sense
lower fault currents if the downstream integrated RES share
increases, 2) False or sympathetic tripping, i.e. due to the
bidirectional fault current ﬂow a relay in a healthy feeder
may trip on the backward fault current, 3) Islanding problems
in microgrids [33], in which the fault current magnitude and
direction changes from grid-connected to islanded mode and 4)
Loss of coordination, i.e. a sequential false operation of relays,
which may also impact the distance relays of the transmission
systems, in which false tripping due to under- or over-reach
issues of the protection zone may result. Consequently, faults
within the protection region may be overseen (under-reach)

III. S MART TRANSFORMER
The Smart Transformer (ST) is a power electronics-based
transformer with advanced control functionalities to allow ﬂex-
ible AC and DC distribution and the possibility to provide grid
services [13]. Thus, it is not a one-by-one replacement of the
conventional transformer [37] with the limited functionality
to step up/down the voltage between primary and secondary
side, but instead forms an active and smart node to allow
high penetration of distributed renewable energy, integration
of storage in the electric distribution grid and electriﬁcation
of transport and heating [38].
The ST is also known as energy router [39] or energy hub,
which describes its main responsibility in the power system:
To manage the transmission and distribution of energy (similar
to an information network) and allow for dynamic adjustments
of energy ﬂow [40] and real-time communication among grid
elements [41]. As explained with more details in the following
sections, the ST can measure grid variables, observe the grid
status and perform optimization and complex control tasks.
In the demonstrator project LV-Engine [42] a ﬁt-for-purpose
ST is intended to be implemented in the secondary substation
of the Scottish distribution grid with the aim to enhance the
ﬂexibility and release more capacity for the connection of
low carbon technologies. The project LV-Engine establishes
ﬁve main use cases of the ST in the near future, which are
optimum real time phase voltage regulation through GFM
mode, a meshed LV network operation, the provision of LVDC
supply for electric vehicles charging, phase balancing and
power capacity sharing between secondary substations.
The replacement of conventional transformers by their smart
counterpart has to be understood as a process. However,
already smaller share of ST in the grid brings improvements
in terms of released capacity in existing LV network for
connection of future RES generation and load prior to costly
grid reinforcements, the increased ﬂexibility and adaptability
to cope with uncertainties in how energy will be generated and
consumed and lastly the expected avoidance of losses through
more efﬁcient DC based integration of EV charging. Thus, the
project LV-Engine expects ﬁnancial savings of 62 million £by
2030 and 528 million £ by 2050 with only 16% of GBs 11
kV / LV transformers being substituted by 2050.
Another recent utilization of the ST can be found in the
German initiative ENSURE [43], in which ﬁeld trials of the
ST in a hybrid AC/DC grid infrastructure at distribution grid
level are carried out with the aim to efﬁciently integrate EV
charging infrastructure and PV systems.
A. Smart Transformer Control in Hybrid and Meshed Grids
The classical conﬁguration of the distribution grid is a radial
ac grid. However, the increasing share of RES and the need
to efﬁciently integrate storage or EV charging stations calls
for hybrid and meshed distribution grids, which combine dc
and ac grids and allow more ﬂexible power ﬂow as each grid
node is at least supplied from two sides [44]. The ST, even
when operated in parallel with conventional transformers [45],
can be seen as an enabler of such grid scenario as it provides
dc connectivity [46] and allows to route the energy ﬂow, i.e.,
in contrast to conventional secondary substation transformers,
can control the active and reactive power exchange with the
connected grids [40].

B. Smart Transformer Grid Services
What makes the STsmart are the advanced control func-
tionalities and the distribution grid services that are enabled
thereof [58]. In Table III, a classiﬁcation of the potential
services that a three-stage ST can provide to the MV ac and
LV ac grid, as well as, the advantages that are facilitated by
the dc connectivity is given.
A strategy using the ST to identify the load dependence
on the grid voltage in real-time by means of intentional small
voltage perturbations and capturing the respective load power
response has been proposed [59]. The knowledge on load
sensitivity allows a proper and smooth control action, for
instance, voltage control for stability purposes or voltage and
frequency regulation, under an increased demand variability
and different loading conditions in the power grid.
A soft load reduction control to avoid load shedding has
been developed, which enables the ST to decrease the con-
sumed load active power by controlling the voltage in the LV
grid according to the identiﬁed load sensitivity [60]. Likewise,
the ST can guarantee a pre-speciﬁed load ﬂexibility to the
transmission or distribution system operator and maintain
its own operational safety by means of overload control.
Moreover, the load control can be applied to improve the
voltage proﬁle in the MV grid prior to the action of on-load
tap changers [61].
The reduction of the grid equivalent inertia due to the
increasing number of PE-connected DG units requests a
frequency regulation with high dynamics. The ST can pro-
vide such service by controlling the load consumption as
power reserve, both upward and downward, during frequency
variations [62]. A study case in the Irish transmission grid
system with wide-spread use of ST has been investigated,
introducing a ﬂexible demand control to support the frequency
and simultaneously the voltage by reactive power control with
the aim to increase the grid’s hosting capacity for renewable
energy systems. A 10 % increase in wind penetration without
any additional storage units has been achieved [6].
As countermeasure towards the reverse power ﬂow from the
LV to MV side of the distribution grid in the case of high DG
power generation and low load demand, the ST can modify
the voltage waveform by varying the frequency in the LV grid
in order to interact with the local DG units, which in turn will
vary their power output avoiding the reverse power ﬂow and
possible voltage rise in the MV side [63].
The ST can be exploited to enhance the possibility of
islanding operation in multi-microgrids. Multi-microgrids are
deﬁned as MV grid interconnecting several aggregated LV
microgrids aiming to increase the distribution grid resilience.
In [64] robust control strategies for ST with and without
integrated storage units have been presented, which aim to
coordinate the ﬂexibility of distributed resources in LV and
MV grid as well as the optional storage unit in order to
guarantee a successful multi-microgrid operation in islanded
mode. The ST can be controlled such that the LV microgrid
frequency is modulated following the MV grid frequency,
which allows the participation of LV DGs in the MV primary
frequency regulation. Furthermore, the storage unit integrated
in the ST LV dc link enables the restoration of the LV MG
frequency, once the MV frequency is resettled within the dead-
band limits.
The control concepts established for the islanding operation
can be extended to a local black start operation in case of
upstream voltage level blackout or fault in the HV grid. The
ST LV inverter will transit to GFM and especially if equipped
with ESS will be able to initiate a soft-start [65] preventing the
ST from high inrush currents and maintaining balanced MV
dc-link voltages [66] and create references for the frequency
and voltage in the multi-microgrid with the aim to recover
pre-fault conditions of load and generation levels and ﬁnally
to allow the re-synchronization to the upstream grid [67].
Forming a non-synchronous interconnection between the LV
and MV ac grids, the ST decouples the two and hence prevents
harmonic propagation from one side to the other. In addition,
the advanced control functionalities allow further improvement
of grid power quality in terms of harmonics and resonances.
As demonstrated in [68], the ST can effectively reduce the
unbalance degree in the MV grid and considerably improve
the current quality in MV and voltage quality in LV grid. The
ST can actively identify grid resonances by mono-frequency
excitation to allow resonance adaptivity of the grid forming
control strategy to LV grid variations [69]. Moreover, the ST
can be seamlessly equipped with ﬁlter-based or multi-loop-
based active damping controller to shape its output impedance,
damp possible grid resonances and increase the grid stability
and the stability of the local DG controllers [70].

C. Smart Transformer Maintenance-oriented Control
Reliability and maintenance costs are still key concerns for
the ST [72], in which an industry survey identiﬁed the thermal
stress of power semiconductors and capacitors as the main
source of failure [73].
As demonstrated in the European Research Council (ERC)
Consolidator Grant HEART (Highly Efﬁcient And Reliable
smart Transformer) and the following ERC Proof of Concept
Grant U-HEART (Unbreakable- Highly Efﬁcient and Reliable
smart Transformer) modularity in the design, i.e., serial or
parallel connection of basic power electronic building blocks,
creates inherent fault tolerant capability and self-healing fea-
tures to increase the STs robustness and reliability [72].
A software-based approach to reduce the thermal stress on
the STs components is given by the active thermal control
[74]. Due to the activation and deactivation of PEBBs to in-
crease the STs efﬁciency, different components are exposed to
different failure mechanisms and stress. However, to increase
the system reliability and avoid or delay as much as possible
the failures dependent on the processed power, the PEBBs
can be unequally loaded (which is referred to as ”Power
Routing”) to shift the stress from older to newer components
[74] considering the estimation of the junction temperature on
the basis of thermo-sensitive electrical parameters [75], and
the remaining useful lifetime. Likewise, lower safety margins
and thus a lighter infrastructure can be realized [72].
The active thermal control (ATC) concept can be imple-
mented at different layers [75] ranging from modulation,
changing the switching frequency or modulation type [76],
[77], to converter or system level control, where the dc-link
voltage control can be adapted or the active/ reactive power
proﬁles can be reshaped introducing virtual resistors to mirror
the aging of the individual PEBBs [78]. This power routing
concept is applied to increase the remaining useful lifetime,
reduce the maintenance costs and increase the availability of
power supply and grid services through prognostic mainte-
nance [79].
D. Remaining Challenges
In the recent decade, several implementation issues of STs
have been sorted. However, there are still some technological
and economic challenges to overcome before SSTs fully
replace conventional transformers [40]. These challenges are
summarized below.
STs are still more expensive than traditional transformers.
However, semiconductor technology is continuously improv-
ing, developing new efﬁcient and cheaper high voltage/current
semiconductor devices. Modular design enables self-healing
features, i.e., the correct fault operation bypassing damaged
powers cells. In fact, a modular design allows reduce the power
outing and balance the aging cell effects, thus failure rate is
reduced and their lifetime is improved. Furthermore, a ST
conﬁguration requires an high-frequency isolation transformer,
then the incorporation of fast semiconductor devices can be
potentially good for ST operation [80]. In this sense, the
utilization of new highly efﬁcient components, such as fast
high-voltage Si-IGBTs, SiC-MOSFETs and GaN-HEMTs will
open new research lines. One of the major beneﬁts attained
from the utilization of wide bandgap devices arises from their
ability to operate at high switching frequencies while still
maintaining a high efﬁciency. Moreover, the increase of the
breakdown voltage, enabled by the development of HV SiC
devices, translates into the utilization of fewer devices in a
topology. The collection of these two aspects contribute to
a reduced footprint, system losses (once the technology is
matured) and CO2 emissions. Although extremely beneﬁcial,
the challenges attached to their full utilization still need to
be completely addressed. From the series arrangement of the
SiC dies and challenges in managing the high dv/dt [81] to
the requirements for appropriate packages, able to ensure the
high voltage insulation and good thermal performance, these
devices have not yet found a mass scale opportunity to bring
down their prices and make them competitive with Si-based
solutions [82].
Other relevant operation challenges such as increased over-
current and overvoltage capabilities during grid faults, fault de-
tection and precise synchronization methods based on spread
communication lines and real-time security algorithms must
be adopted and solved in order to increase the robustness of
ST substations. Finally, there are still several challenges to in-
crease the utilization of STs into the power grid. Developing of
new standards and grid codes oriented to deﬁne the interaction
between STs and the power grid is a mandatory task in order
to make ST an industrial product [40].
IV . HVDCSYSTEMS
HVDC have proved to be cost efﬁcient alternative to
ac transmission for long distance energy transmission due
to the lower cost of lines and reduced same right-of-way
(RoW) [83]. Urban areas infeed and off-shore wind farms
using underground or submarine cable also beneﬁts from this
technology [84]. The interconnection of asynchronous grids,
even with different frequencies, can also take advantage of
this technology using back-to-back systems in which there
is no transmission line involved [85]. The fast dynamical
9
response, improved stability and distributed control capability
of HVDC might be the key to increase renewable energies
utilization [86]. Moreover, HVDC can be embedded in the
legacy AC power system [87]. Increasing the interconnectivity,
the embedded HVDC has the potential to reinforce the hosting
capacity of the AC grid by providing control services and thus
reducing the investment needed in terms of conventional grid
infrastructure upgrades.
HVDC technology is rather mature, but as the number
of HVDC in worldwide power systems is increasing new
challenges have been emerged. Reduction of interarea sub-
synchronous oscillations, fast frequency regulation, weak grid
operation and protection strategies for increasing reliability are
some of them. In this section a review of HVDC technologies
and recent advances on the topics mentioned previously are
discussed.
A. HVDC Technologies
Thyristor based HVDC technology was introduced in the
1970 decade proving to be lighter, cheaper, more reliable and
more efﬁcient than the previous technology based on mercury
valves [88]. This HVDC technology uses line commutated
converters (LCC) which are composed by an arrangement
of six switches, each one made of several semiconductors
connected in series to achieve the transmission DC voltage
range. To control the DC voltage and hence the active power,
the ﬁring angle is modiﬁed and, intrinsically, there is a
coupled relationship between active and reactive power. These
converters requires reactive power and cannot be connected to
passive grids which do not have voltage sources in the AC side
or weak grids where the reactive power could not be properly
controlled.
The six pulse rectiﬁer generates characteristic harmonics
in the ac current and in the dc voltage requiring large ﬁlters
in both sides. It is possible to connect several six-pulse
rectiﬁers using a transformer with phase-shifted secondaries
generating a multipulse input current (12/24/36 pulses). In Fig.
8 a) is depicted a 12-pulse LCC-based HVDC system. This
conﬁguration reduces the harmonics in the DC voltage and
AC current but also reduces the overall efﬁciency due to the
transformer [89]. The reactive power requirements of LCC-
based HVDC can be reduced by using Capacitor Commutated
Converters (CCC) as is presented in Fig. 8 b).
V oltage source converters (VSC) with force commutated
semiconductors (IGBT) were introduced in HVDC systems
employing modular multilevel converter (MMC). The main
advantage of this topology is that the generated voltage is
composed by several small voltage steps, hence important
improvements are obtained as such as minimization of har-
monic generation, elimination of the input ﬁlter, low HF
noise, low switching losses, low semiconductor switching
frequency, and nearly sinusoidal AC voltage waveforms. These
converters do not require any reactive power compensation,
and moreover they can control independently both active and
reactive power with high dynamic, hence these converters can
be connected to weak networks and even to passive networks
without synchronous generators in it. However, compared to

V. CHALLENGES TO INTEGRATE HVDC INTO ELECTRICAL
GRIDS
New power converter technologies based on voltage source
converters have pushed the use of HVDC on new applications
resulting in a wide variety of challenges which must be
addressed during the next years. Most of these challenges are
summarized in Table IV and they are related to the growth of
renewable energy sources integrated to the electrical system
in order to increase efﬁciency, stability and reliability. In this
section several of these challenges are described.
A. Sub Synchronous Interarea oscillations
The interaction of the HVDC controllers and the mechanical
time constant of the ac machines can lead to low frequency
oscillations also called as sub synchronous resonances (SSR).
These resonances might lead to large voltage and currents
excursions damaging the system components and activating
the protection devices. Even when these resonances are limited
in amplitude, if they are generated continuously, torsional
oscillations can lead to the fatigue and eventual failure of the
rotating machines.
The LCC-HVDC can generate SSR if the equivalent
impedance generate by the rectiﬁer station has a strong modal
resonance. The solution proposed to reduce these oscillations
is modifying the tuning of the controller parameters in order
to generate active damping [98].
This effect is less likely to occur in VSC-HVDC because
the dynamics of the controllers are faster than LCC-HVDC.
However, it has been demonstrated, using modal frequency
linear analysis, that this effect can be still produced, particu-
larly if the HVDC station is implemented with constant power
control. In this condition the impedance is reduced and there
exists a small damping to avoid oscillations [99].
Interarea SSR can be also generated by the primary control
implemented in the HVDC station for frequency regulation.
This type of interaction between the primary control and
mechanical elements of the grid can lead to very slow SSR in
the order of 0.1-0.7Hz and, which can be avoided, or at least
reduced, by a proper design of the controller [100].
Although the main cause of SSR is the interaction of the
controller with mechanical devices, for long lines it can also be
produced in the HVDC line by an oscillating power exchange
between stations. The DC ﬁlters increase the resonance peak
and, in this case, it is possible to reduce it by limiting the gain
of the controller for subsynchronous frequencies [101].
Another cause of SSR is in multiterminal HVDC due to
the master-slave conﬁguration in which there is only one
station controlling the DC voltage and all the other stations are
controlling power. In these cases the most commonly proposed
solution is to model a resistor in series with the DC line into
the control system in order to produce virtual damping [102].
The main challenge to reduce SSR is the requirement to
perform a modal analysis of the system in order to model the
coupling between the HVDC and ac systems and identify the
cause of the oscillation. This task is not trivial and required a
detailed knowledge of the parameters of lines and generators,
as well as, the different conﬁgurations of the grid [103].

B. Fast frequency regulation
Large-scale integration of renewable energy has increasingly
reduced the inertia of power systems because this kind of
energy sources does not provide any inertia in the case of
photo-voltaic solar energy and only a very little mechanical
inertia in the case of wind power. The reduction of the system
inertia might lead to larger and faster frequency deviations
which can activate protection systems and reduce their sta-
bility. Note that, the implementation of the synthetic inertia
concept in power systems with high penetration of renewable
energy sources is performed with a derated maximum power-
point tracking (MPPT) operation also named ﬂexible MPP and
energy storage source installations.
In this scenario, VSC-HVDC, due to the fast dynamical
response of currents, can be used to alleviate this problem by
incorporating synthetic inertia and damping into the system.
The control system of the HVDC must be modiﬁed to mimic
the behavior of a synchronous machine in which the frequency
is related to the power extracted or injected, hence from the
point of view of the grid, and the HVDC station becomes a
large synchronous machine with synthetic mechanical inertia
associated.
Similar to a mechanical system, the slow rate of change of
frequency provided by the inertia consumes or adds kinetic
12
energy from the rotating machine. With synthetic inertia, the
energy comes from the DC terminals of the HVDC station,
which doesn’t inherently have an energy storage system to
cope with the energy. Several methods to provide this energy
from the DC-link have been proposed, such as increasing the
DC capacitance by installing distributed capacitors along the
DC line [107]. The DC voltage can also be modiﬁed to provide
this energy, but in HVDC systems, there are strict limitations
regarding DC voltage due to isolation and operation issues
[108].
In a multi-terminal HVDC conﬁguration with a master-slave
control scheme, the energy required to provide synthetic inertia
can be easily obtained from the master station as well as the
AC system is large enough to be considered as an inﬁnite
system [109]. Distributed battery energy storage connected to
each submodule of the HVDC station can provide the required
energy to implement synthetic inertia. The main challenge of
this alternative is the internal current and energy control to
keep the batteries charged without compromise the control
of AC and DC currents [110]. As an alternative to battery
energy storage installation, the HVDC can be also equipped
with additional controller to exploit the energy reserve of
nearby ﬂexible voltage-dependent loads to implement primary
frequency control or synthetic inertia [111].
Finally, in offshore wind farms connected by an HVDC
link to the coast, the inland station can provide synthetic
inertia using the kinetic energy of the wind turbines. Although
this energy can be obtained by coordinating both HVDC
stations, a communication-free strategy is preferred in which
the synthetic inertia control extracts energy from the DC line
and the other station detects the variation of DC voltage and
compensate it by extracting the energy from the turbines [112].
C. Operation with weak grids
Weak grids are electrical systems in which the frequency
and voltage amplitude have large variations depending on the
operating conditions. The deﬁnition of a weak grid involves
its impedance and inertia.
Depending on the HVDC technology the interaction with
weak grids can be completely different. HVDC systems based
on LCC are usually focused on bulk energy transmission and
hence there are not designed to be connected to small weak
grids. The use of thyristors requires a precise synchronization
with the grid frequency and the amplitude of the voltage must
be stable for proper polarization of the semiconductors. In
weak grids both features are variable, hence the performance
of the LCC-HVDC can be affected. On the other hand, the
phase angle control couples the active and reactive power and
a capacitor bank to provide reactive power compensation is
usually designed for the nominal operation. In the case of
weak grids, this capacitor can overcompensate reactive power
leading to a reduced power factor and increasing the voltage
amplitude. Although these drawbacks, it is possible to modify
the HVDC station and its control to operate with weak grids if
necessary, for example, to power transmission to islands [113].
Alternatively, and hybrid HVDC composed by a CCC-
HVDC connected in series with a VSC-HVDC can reduce the
reactive power required by the station allowing its use into
weak grids [114].
The preferred choice to connect weak grids is using VSC-
HVDC both in GFL and GFM operation. In GFL operation the
amount of transferred power is directly linked with the margin
of stability, hence in a weak grid there exists a limitation
to the transferred power [115]. In this condition, the vector
control cannot operate with large power demand, but it can
be modiﬁed tuning its parameters with a slower dynamics and
generating a virtual voltage to improve synchronization [116].
Grid forming operation of VSC-HVDC can provide a more
suitable connection to weak grids integrating the HVDC as a
power generator which helps to stabilize the grid. A frequency-
based synchronization control has been proposed in which the
HVDC can provide the nominal power and is not affected
by variation in the system frequency. In case of failure, to
avoid high currents the internal loop can be switched to vector
control [117].
D. HVDC breakers and fault protection
A mechanical switch with a resonant circuit to provide zero
crossing current can be employed to implement a DC circuit
breaker (DCCB) using a full bridge circuit to simplify the de-
sign of the oscillation cycle and provide consecutive interrup-
tion capability [118]. Combining surge arresters, mechanical
switches, semiconductor devices and current limiters a circuit
breaker can be implemented. The precise synchronization of
these devices into the DCCB is a key factor to avoid large
overvoltages [119].
LCC-HVDC suffer commutation failures which can lead to
high currents through the devices and might destroy them. To
mitigate this failure a predictive strategy in which the phase
angle of the device is modiﬁed in order to reduce the effect
of the failure has been proposed [120].
VSC-HVDC can provide DC fault capability by changing
the design of the submodules in the MMC. However, this
alternative allows large currents to circulate through the MMC
and increase the costs. The mechanical and semiconductor
hybrid DCCB with an active short-circuit path to ground
can be used in the MMC providing fast fault current clear-
ance without large current circulating through the submodules
[121]. However, the design of hybrid DCCB is complex and
has to be evaluated in a large variety of grid conditions, for
which fast and precise analytical methods are required [122].
A combination of an ac circuit breaker (ACCB) and the
operation of the MMC itself is proposed to manage both ac
and dc faults. In the event of ac faults the ACCB operates as its
normal operation and for DC faults the converter is conﬁgured
in a way also the ACCB clears the faults. In order to proper
operation this structure requires a fast detection of dc faults
[123].
The single-phase to ground is the most common ac fault.
In this condition a voltage sag is produced and the MMC
requires an strategy to avoid capacitor over-voltages and
provide fault tolerant operation isolating the fault from the
dc side. Therefore, the power of the HVDC system is not
reduced during the failure. A compensation control strategy
13
can be developed to detect the unbalanced voltages and act
over the current references to achieve the mentioned goals
[124].
Fault protection in DC systems is challenging because short
circuit current has a very fast dynamic. The peak amplitude of
the short circuit current is necessary for conventional DCCB
and ACCB correct operation. Thus, ultrafast fault detection,
location and protection is still a mandatory challenge particu-
larly in HVDC and ESS. Thus, the development of solid-state
circuit breakers (SSCB) solutions are designed to meet the
challenging protection speed and power density required by
future power grid.
VI. C ONCLUSION AND FUTURE TRENDS
System level ”power electronics” solutions for the electric
grid both in the voltage adaptation and power transfer are
discussed in a common perspective in the paper. Both the
presented technologies shall have the capability to operate in
grid-forming mode despite in meshed-grid operation also grid-
following mode is requested. Protections are also highlighted
as a key technology where a strong interaction with power
electronics is expected. The possibility to inﬂuence the grid
voltage and consequently the power ﬂow and the connected
loads is found to be one of the key features of smart trans-
former and transmission technologies.
